text: And Abimelech said unto Abraham, What sawest thou, that thou hast done this thing?
text_kjv: And Abimelech said unto Abraham, What sawest thou, that thou hast done this thing?
text_niv: And Abimelech asked Abraham, “What was your reason for doing this?”
text_esv: And Abimelech said to Abraham, “What did you see, that you did this thing?”
text_nlt: Whatever possessed you to do such a thing?”
text_msg: Abimelech went on to Abraham, "Whatever were you thinking of when you did this thing?"
text_nasb: And Abimelech said to Abraham, 'What have you encountered, that you have done this thing?'
context: Genesis 20:10 occurs within a narrative where Abraham sojourns in Gerar, a Philistine territory ruled by King Abimelech. The Philistines of this era were not the later maritime people known from the books of Judges and Samuel; these were likely an earlier, less defined group. Abimelech, as a king, held significant power, and his interaction with Abraham highlights the precarious position of nomadic groups within settled kingdoms. Hospitality was paramount in ancient Near Eastern cultures, but so was protection of one’s household, especially women. Abraham's deceptive claim that Sarah was his sister endangered Abimelech's kingdom. The idea of tribal loyalty and kinship bonds was strong. Abraham, as a relative newcomer, would have relied on establishing a degree of trust with the ruling authority to ensure his safety and the well-being of his family. The repetition of this 'sister' deception (also seen in Genesis 12 with Pharaoh) suggests a pattern rooted in Abraham's deep-seated fear for his life, outweighing his trust in God's protection. It also reveals a potential understanding of the perceived value and vulnerability of women in that society, where a husband's claim could provide better protection than being a wife. Kings had the power to take any woman they desired, making Sarah a potential target. Therefore, Abraham's lie reflects both the anxieties and social dynamics of the time.
meaning: Abimelech's question, "What sawest thou, that thou hast done this thing?", cuts to the core of Abraham's actions and exposes the spiritual deficiencies underlying them. This verse is a poignant moment where a pagan king implicitly rebukes the patriarch of faith. Abimelech, while not a worshiper of Yahweh, possesses a sense of justice and morality that Abraham, in this instance, lacks. Abraham’s fear motivated his deception. He prioritizes his own life over Sarah's safety and God’s promises. Abraham, a figure chosen by God to be the father of a great nation and a blessing to all peoples, is acting out of fear, revealing a lack of trust in God’s sovereignty. This raises questions about faith and obedience. Did Abraham genuinely believe God would protect him, or did his fear outweigh his faith? The incident highlights the struggle between human fallibility and divine purpose. Even those chosen by God can stumble. Abraham's actions have serious consequences: they jeopardize Sarah's purity, threaten Abimelech's kingdom with divine judgment, and bring potential dishonor upon God’s name. This verse serves as a stark reminder that faith is not merely intellectual assent but a living, breathing trust that informs every action. It also presents an interesting dynamic where a non-believer challenges a believer's moral compass, forcing introspection and accountability.
application: Abimelech's question resonates profoundly in our modern lives. We, like Abraham, often make decisions driven by fear, self-preservation, or convenience, rather than by faith and integrity. "What sawest thou, that thou hast done this thing?" can be a powerful question to ask ourselves when evaluating our own choices. Consider moments when you compromised your values for personal gain, withheld the truth to avoid conflict, or prioritized comfort over doing what is right. What 'fear' or 'insecurity' motivated these actions? This verse challenges us to examine the underlying motivations behind our choices. Are we acting out of trust in God's provision and protection, or are we driven by fear and a desire to control our circumstances? We must be willing to confront our own blind spots and acknowledge the times when we have fallen short of living according to God's standards. Seeking counsel from trusted friends, mentors, or spiritual leaders can provide valuable perspective and help us identify patterns of behavior rooted in fear rather than faith. We can cultivate integrity by practicing honesty in all our dealings, even when it is difficult. Remember that living a life of faith requires courage and a willingness to trust God, even when the path ahead is uncertain. We can actively work on recognizing and counteracting our fears through prayer, scripture reading, and focusing on God's promises. Ultimately, we are called to be ambassadors of Christ, reflecting His character in all that we do. This requires constant self-reflection and a commitment to living according to God's truth, even when it is challenging.
prayer: Heavenly Father, forgive me for the times I have allowed fear to dictate my actions instead of trusting in Your power and love. Help me to recognize the moments when I am acting out of insecurity or self-preservation, and grant me the courage to choose faith over fear. Give me discernment to see my own blind spots and the humility to seek wise counsel. Empower me to live a life of integrity, reflecting Your character in all that I do. I ask for Your protection and guidance as I navigate the challenges of this world. May my actions always bring honor to Your name. Help me trust in Your provision and sovereignty. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: Abraham's repetition of the lie likely stems from a deep-seated fear of losing his life. He learned from his previous experience in Egypt that his wife's beauty put him at risk, and he hadn't grown in faith to trust God for protection in this similar situation.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Why did Abraham repeat the same lie he told Pharaoh?

faqs.answer: While Abimelech displays a sense of justice and morality lacking in Abraham's actions here, it's not necessarily a judgment of character overall. The passage highlights Abraham's lapse in faith, not Abimelech's inherent superiority.
faqs.question: Q2: Is Abimelech presented as a 'better' person than Abraham in this passage?

faqs.answer: This passage clearly illustrates the tension between faith and fear. Fear can undermine faith, leading to choices that contradict God's will. It underscores the importance of actively choosing faith even when afraid.
faqs.question: Q3: What does this passage teach us about the relationship between faith and fear?

faqs.answer: The incident reveals Abraham's humanity and imperfection. It shows that even those chosen by God can struggle with doubt and fear, reminding us that faith is a journey, not a destination. His failures humanize him.
faqs.question: Q4: How does this incident affect Abraham's role as the father of faith?

faqs.answer: Abraham's actions have implications as they become part of the history of the covenant people. It shows that even the forefathers made mistakes and teaches reliance on God for guidance, forgiveness and for future generations to learn from.
faqs.question: Q5: What are the implications of Abraham's actions for his descendants?
